message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Lacunar strokes are small, deep infarcts that produce focal neurologic deficits. Hemiballismus is an involuntary movement disorder characterized by sudden, wild, flailing movements of the limbs on one side of the body, which would be the most likely finding on physical examination in this case. Cogwheel rigidity and dystonia are associated with Parkinson's disease, and vertical gaze palsy is associated with midbrain lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A lacunar stroke involving the subthalamic nucleus can present with hemiballismus, which is characterized by sudden, flinging, and violent movements of one side of the body. Cogwheel rigidity and dystonia are commonly seen in Parkinson's disease, while vertical gaze palsy is associated with brainstem lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A lacunar stroke involving the subthalamic nucleus can cause hemiballismus, which is characterized by sudden, forceful, and wild movements of the limbs on one side of the body. Cogwheel rigidity and dystonia are associated with Parkinson's disease and other movement disorders. Vertical gaze palsy may occur with brainstem lesions or disorders affecting the ocular motor nerves.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A lacunar stroke involving the subthalamic nucleus can cause hemiballismus, which is characterized by sudden, forceful, jerky and flinging movements almost always involving the contralateral side to the lesion. Cogwheel rigidity and dystonia are seen in Parkinson's disease, while vertical gaze palsy is seen in brainstem lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A lacunar stroke affecting the subthalamic nucleus can cause hemiballismus, which is characterized by sudden and wild flinging movements of the limbs on one side of the body. Cogwheel rigidity is commonly seen in Parkinson's disease, dystonia is characterized by sustained muscle contractions that cause twisting and repetitive movements, and vertical gaze palsy is a neurological condition characterized by the inability to direct the eyes in a vertical direction. None of these findings are consistent with a lacunar stroke involving the subthalamic nucleus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A lacunar stroke in the subthalamic nucleus can cause hemiballismus, which is characterized by sudden flinging movements of the extremities on one side of the body. Cogwheel rigidity and dystonia are associated with Parkinson's disease, and a vertical gaze palsy is associated with a lesion in the midbrain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A lacunar stroke involving the subthalamic nucleus can cause hemiballismus, which is characterized by sudden, violent, flinging movements of one side of the body. Cogwheel rigidity and dystonia are more commonly associated with Parkinson's disease, while vertical gaze palsy is more commonly seen in brainstem lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Lacunar strokes typically present with pure motor or sensory deficits, or a combination of the two. Hemiballismus, which is characterized by uncontrollable flinging movements of the limbs on one side of the body, is a possible presentation of lacunar stroke involving the subthalamic nucleus. Cogwheel rigidity and dystonia are typically seen in Parkinson’s disease, and vertical gaze palsy is associated with brainstem lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A lacunar stroke involving the subthalamic nucleus can cause involuntary flinging movements of the limbs on one side of the body, known as hemiballismus. Among the options, cogwheel rigidity and dystonia are associated with Parkinson’s disease, and vertical gaze palsy is associated with brainstem or cerebellar dysfunction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The CT scan findings suggest a lacunar stroke, and among the options, only hemiballismus is associated with subthalamic nucleus involvement. Cogwheel rigidity and dystonia are associated with basal ganglia involvement, while vertical gaze palsy is associated with midbrain involvement.
